isis.stitle: T 444E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1997) - SECTION 5.3: MULTIMETER USE - USING THE VOLTMETER

svcsubsecinfo.para: In electrical diagnosis, the voltmeter is used to answer:

item.para: What is the voltage drop across a load device?

svcsubsecinfo.para:
When using a voltmeter to determine if voltage is present to power a device, connect the positive meter lead to input connection of the device (positive side) and connect the negative meter lead to good vehicle ground ( Figure 5.52
). This shows how much of the source voltage is available to the device. Note that the meter is connected in parallel to the device.

figure.caption: Figure 5.52 - Checking Power To A Load Device

svcsubsecinfo.para:
Should we need to determine if voltage is available at a connector where we can't readily connect to the device, we can connect the meter in parallel as shown in ( Figure 5.53
). The meter internal resistance is very high so little current will flow in the circuit, and the voltage can be read accurately.

To check the voltage drop across a load device ( Figure 5.54
), connect the positive lead of the voltmeter to the positive side of the device and the negative meter lead to the negative side of the device.

figure.caption: Figure 5.53 - Checking Power To A Connector

svcsubsecinfo.para:
With the device operating, this will measure the voltage drop across the device. Notice in (Figure 5.54)
that since we only have one device, all of the voltage should be dropped at the device. In any circuit, the voltage applied will equal the voltage dropped in the circuit. If in this circuit we only dropped 9V across the load, that would indicate that our wires, connections, etc. were dropping the other 3V, which would indicate excessive circuit resistance.
